title: CTRL0000050991 - Transcribed Interview of James Douglas Rahm III, (March 4, 2022)

data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The interview in the above matter was held via Webex, commencing at 10:04 a.m.
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
For the COMMITTEE ON HOUSE ADMINISTRATION:
This is the transcribed interview of James Douglas Rahm, 111,
conducted by the House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the
United States Capitol pursuant to House Resolution 503.
At this time, I'd ask the witness to please state your full name and then spell your
This will be a staff-led interview.
I don't expect that to happen, but it's possible.
And then, as I explained before, I'll be asking most of the questions.
be asking some questions as well.
Members of the committee may join at some
And if a member joins, it's possible that they would
And then, just for the record, speaking i s - investigative counsel with
t h e ~ is also in the room, and he's a professional staff member with the select
We've also g o t - also an investigative counsel.
We've got a couple of court reporters and other staff members that will be
helping us with logistical things throughout the interview.
And then also, Ms. Shaner, could I have you state your name for the record,
Heather Shaner, counsel for James Rahm, Ill.
And then, James, I understand we will be addressing you as JD, short for James
As I mentioned, we've got a couple reporters on the line, court reporters.
be taking a transcription of the interview.
to wait until I finish asking a question before you begin your answer, and then I'll do the
same thing, wait for you to finish your answer before I start a new question.
very hard for them to record when there's two people talking at the same time.
So, to make their life a little bit easier, just try
And then, also kind of relatedly, they can only record verbal
responses, so try not to shake your head yes or no.
Use a verbal yes or no.
if -- you know, we all make that mistake sometimes, so if I need to, I might prompt you to
And then today all we're asking of you is to provide complete
answers to the best of your recollection.
If a question I ask isn't clear, which happens
sometimes, just ask me to rephrase the question or ask for clarification.
And then, if you don't know the answer to a question, just simply say so.
There are a few kind of background or ground rules that we should
go over before we get into questions.
The first is that it's important that you understand that today is a voluntary
If at any time you want to stop speaking with us, that's your choice.
Similarly, if at any point you need to take a break to talk to your counsel in private,
just let us know and we can all take a break, turn off our cameras and mikes, and you can
talk with Ms. Shaner if you need to.
While this interview is voluntary and it's not under oath, it's important that you
understand that, because this is a formal congressional investigation, you're obligated
under Federal law to tell the truth, the same as if you were speaking to FBI or DOJ.
So it's unlawful to deliberately provide false information to Congress.
interview, providing false information could result in criminal penalties for false
And then also, you're not obligated to keep the fact of this interview or what we
You're free to tell whomever you wish that you met with us,
including the prosecutor or the judge in your case, or you could tell nobody at all.
And then also, I just want you to understand that the select
committee is separate and distinct from the DOJ.
prosecutions, and the DOJ is not a partner of the select committee in this investigation.
We don't have any involvement in the
Kind of similarly, the select committee is not a party to your criminal case and isn't
agreeing to submit anything on your behalf to the judge, nor can we make any
representations whether, if you tell the judge that you met us, that the judge will be more
favorable to you at the end of your case during sentencing.
And then lastly, in general we will not be sharing our conversation
tell the truth during the interview, that could potentially trigger an obligation to share
some of that information with the DOJ.
we don't think the DOJ is currently aware of, then that could also trigger a similar
There are a couple possible exceptions to that.
If we felt like you did not
Or if you gave us information about a crime that
And then also, just let us know throughout the interview if
you need a break at any point to use the bathroom, get some water, or just need a
minute or two, and I'm happy to take a break at any point.
And then also, as I explained earlier, I'll be asking most of the questions, b u t -
or some others -- other folks might jump in at different points and ask some follow-up
Then with that, I think we can start.
And I just want to start with a
little bit of background information about you.
If you could just tell me how old you are and where you're from.
Twenty-seven, and I live in Atlantic City, New Jersey.
I was working and living in Philadelphia, but ever since COVID I've been living
And did you grow up there?
How long have you been in Atlantic City?
And before that were you in Philadelphia?
And who -- what's your living situation now?
back with my mother in Atlantic City.
And then can you give us a quick run-through of your educational
I've gone to Catholic school my whole life, including university, Holy
Spirit High School in Absecon, New Jersey, and then La Salle University in Philadelphia.
And I graduated with a bachelor degree in business administration.
And then I know you said that you are living with your mother.
Do your mother and father live together?
And when was that that you graduated?
And then, sorry, you might have mentioned this, but what do you do
and Shi pt and those kind of things.
And then I also do like the
I just started doing those actually, like it's like Grubhub
I was doing construction full time in Philadelphia up until COVID kind of shut
I'm back in Atlantic City now.
And then our company never survived COVID actually.
Let's move to kind of discussing the period just before the general election in
2020 and kind of time before that.
political activity kind of heading into the general election.
I just want to understand generally your level of
I'm not very political at all.
more interested in, you know, just the craziness of it all, where, like, where you would
see, you know, stuff in the streets.
I just -- you know, that's kind of the extent of my political stuff, is just watching
videos online and -- you know, I'm not very political as far as, you know, considering
agree with things, you know, on all sides.
So as far as like politics go, I'm not very heavily involved.
I don't really like to just fall into one side, because I
Leading -- so during the 2020 election, would you say that you were
I'd say to make my parents happy.
But, again, I didn't know enough to
really, you know, make my own decision, I guess.
But, yeah, just because my parents
were, you know, I played with, you know, with that side of it a little, but I wouldn't
consider myself like a Trump supporter.
Had you ever attended any Trump rallies during the election?
That was my first, the, I guess, if you want to call it a rally, on the day
Let's talk a little bit about kind of where you got your political and
news information around that time, so the 2020 timeframe.
Did you watch news on television?
I'd flick through the channels just to see the headlines.
point we didn't have cable anymore.
I don't really remember exactly when that point
watch like, you know, the same channels that, you know, are on cable, have their own

I think just like ABC, NBC, whatever -- honestly, whatever would pop up on
So most of my information all came from like VouTube channels.
So, you know, that's where the majority of my news, like, headlines
my feed that would give me headlines.
I wasn't like actually like searching up a specific
VouTubers if they popped up on my feed.
little clips that the media organizations upload to VouTube.
I'd watch, you know -- sometimes I'd watch different, you know,
But for the most part it was just like those
And most of the ones that -- oh, sorry, go ahead.
Oh, I was just going to say, I wasn't very -- you know, it was just like maybe,
you know, if I saw it here and there, I'd click on it.
would pop up in my feed I would see the headlines.
It wasn't like every day I was like,
It was just kind of like whatever
The networks that you mentioned, you know, ABC, NBC are sort of the
primary couple, two or three networks.
Did you ever look at VouTube news sources of,
so, for example, like lnfoWars or Newsmax, some of the nonprimary networks?
I don't think I was, you know, watching them too
I do remember seeing them pop up here and there on my feed, you know.
And what was the other one you said?
I may have seen -- I'm not extremely familiar with them, but I
may have seen them pop up on my feed as well.
I'm not very familiar with them either.
Andllllmight have been about to ask this.
One America Network, I believe, is the --
So is it fair to say then that you
weren't searching for news, you were trusting the algorithm in sort of what popped up?
I mean, if there was a specific topic I was more interested in on a,
you know, on any given day, maybe I would go search up some more, maybe like on
But, yeah, I wasn't doing that much.
I was just casually watching the headlines, I
And do you have a sense of like how long you would spend watching the
I mean, a few minutes maybe.
I mean, yeah, it didn't really interest me all
How about any print publications, printed news, did you read any of your
And then how about using social media to kind of obtain news?
Like did you use Facebook or anything like that?
No, I'm not very big on Facebook.
I only use Facebook as far as like my DJ
But other than that, the only news I would ever see was on Snapchat, how they
have like the Discover page and like different -- and then, again, it's the major, you know,
media organizations putting out their stories.
So a lot of it was just the same exact thing you'd see on the YouTube videos just,
I have sort of a laundry list of some social media applications, and I'm just
going to run through it quickly with you, and if you tell me if you used the app and then
particularly if you used it for news purposes at all.
I think, I know you mentioned, and I know you've used Snapchat, right?
Did you, when you used Snapchat, did you ever post political
I don't think I ever have.
I mean, maybe a meme or something that I
How about Reddit, did you use Reddit?
But I can't even -- I can't remember me posting anything political.
I know you said Face book mostly just for your DJ'ing.
I maybe -- I've never used like Reddit the app.
when I've been googling certain questions not related to politics where a Reddit thread
would pop up, but that was the extent of my Reddit use.
No, I've never -- I've never had TikTok.
I have Twitter, but I've -- I never really use it.
Do you post content on VouTube?
I have posted stuff related to my DJ career and whatnot, and I think maybe a
You said VouTube was sort of your primary viewing source?
But that would be all that I've posted.
How about -- so following specific individuals.
followed that was kind of politically tied or motivated that you followed on any social
media apps that we just discussed?
Not that I can think of, honestly.
How about President Trump, did you follow President Trump on any social
I don't think so, but I don't know.
maybe I've seen his posts on Twitter back like years ago, like when I actually did like
But I haven't opened it in so long that I don't even know.
But I don't think I was even following him.
I think I maybe have just seen, you
know -- or maybe I've just seen it just from all the internet stuff that you see from his
tweets, and I'm just like misremembering.
But as far as like following, I don't really think
Do you remember seeing any of President Trump's Twitter activity
around the election or the time after, November, December, January?
I mean, like I said, maybe some of the things, you know,
that it would be pulled from Twitter and put into some type of media, but not the actual
I want to ask some of your feelings about the general election.
And just to preface these questions, really we're just interested in kind of understanding
your mindset leading into January 6th, not meaning to kind of cast any disparagement on
any particular views, just kind of want to understand what you thought of the general
So did you, after the general election in early November 2020, did you think that
the election had been stolen from President Trump?
But I just didn't find any -- anything concrete with the little bit of stuff that I did see.
So, yeah, there was nothing that led me to the immediate conclusion:
I mean, I saw a bunch of things that, you know, people were trying to
And, you know, I did look into some things and try to see if anything was valid.
Did you participate in any political activities or any other sorts of rallies after
I think January 6th was the only political event or rally that I've ever
been to in my life, as far as I can remember.
Any other kind of just general feelings about the election or
thoughts that you had at that time that you recall?
I mean, of course, you couldn't get away from the
news, but I wasn't trying to pay attention too deliberately to it all.
And do you mind saying who you voted for?
And did you vote in the election?
But, again, like I said about my parents, I
really just did it to kind of make them happy.
I think ■■lhas a couple questions for you.
What kind of research did you do?
Yeah, just in terms of your thoughts on whether the election was stolen.
Honestly, I did such little stuff that I don't even really remember.
maybe I've -- you know, if I saw something, I'd try to go to like some type of fact-checking
site or something like that just to kind of get some validation to see if that
person -- because maybe I was having like a discussion with somebody, and I thought that
it was a little crazy what they were saying.
I don't really remember the specifics, but I do remember there was a couple
instances where I was like, "All right, let me look into this a little bit," and then didn't
Do you have a sense of how long it took you to debunk some of those
I mean, I'd say I only probably looked into things maybe a few minutes at a
So I didn't really dive too deep.
But it didn't lead me to want to look further, if
So a few minutes was enough then for you to be able to have
the conversation with whoever you were having the conversation with?
And I don't even think I continued that conversation after that.
think it was just something that I heard from somebody in a conversation, and then later,
you know, I kind of looked up on it and then didn't really have any interest to look any
I think it was a friend, yeah.
I'm remembering a specific conversation, and
I'm not remembering exactly who it was.
And so you're remembering one specific conversation, but I think you
How often -- do you remember how many times you went and did this sort of
I'd say only like two or three maybe.
Let's talk about the decision to go to D.C. for the 6th.
When did you start considering that trip?
Well, it was my father's trip that he was going on, and he was going by
And he told me probably on like the 3rd or the 4th that he was thinking about
And at that point it wasn't even really definite for him.
And then I think it was maybe later on the 4th or earlier on the 5th, he said he like
made this spur-of-the-moment decision to get a room and to go.
And, you know, I really -- I wasn't comfortable with letting him just go all by
companion to go with him, his son.
want to see him go alone.
I kind of started to feel bad because he was like looking for, you know, a
And I just decided to go with him because I didn't
One of the other big motivations for me was I had just purchased a Go Pro camera.
Have you ever heard of that?
And after seeing like some of the stuff, like protests and stuff on like
different VouTube videos, you know, kind of like how there would be like different
counterprotesting clashes, I thought that that was kind of a possibility, and I thought it
would be my chance to get, you know, a viral video with my GoPro.
So not wanting my father to go alone, and then wanting to, you know, record
some action, was my kind of main motivation for going to D.C.
Can you describe for me sort of your dad's political activity to the
Was he more active than you were?
I think he's definitely influenced a little easily,
whereas me, like I need to kind of look into things a little bit more.
So, yeah, I mean, he's definitely -- he's not like crazy involved, but he definitely like
Do you know if he had attended any other rallies or -- either in the
post-election period or before, like a Trump rally?
I can't remember if he's ever attended anything.
What was -- as your dad was kind of describing his desire to go down
to D.C. on the 4th and the 5th, what was he telling you about the rallies?
He just was -- I think he was more interested in just like the amount of
people that were going to be there and just thinking like he -- like I could feel like it was a
FOMO kind of thing, like he didn't want to miss out on it.
That was my -- he didn't say that, but that was kind of my feeling, because it was
such just like an, "All right, I'm going to book a room and go."
Yeah, that's as much as I know of like his actual like motivations.
a -- he is a big Trump supporter, so he wanted to go support Donald Trump.
was the extent of, as far as I know, his desires for wanting to go.
You said he was a big Trump supporter.
that he particularly disliked that you heard him talking about?
Like I said, if I knew politics a little bit more, I might be able to remember
Not that I can remember by name.
I mean, you know, he's had comments
I don't really remember the specifics though.
certain names, but I don't know as much as I probably should.
How about Vice President Pence, did you ever hear him talk about him?
Not that I can remember, no.
So it was, you think, later on the 4th or the 5th that he ended up booking a
hotel and making the final decision to go down to D.C.?
Yeah, I think it was probably like early -- earlier on the 5th that I finally made
Sorry, my internet cut out and my computer had some problems.
apologize if you already answered these questions, JD.
But I'm interested in sort of your sense of trying to get a viral video.
to other people who do videos or content about going to January 6th?
No, I didn't really talk to -- I don't really know anybody personally that
Did you get a sense from on line that this was a hot topic for content
creators -- or, sorry, a hot day for content creators?
I was kind of just basing it off of what I've seen in the past.
whenever there's been kind of like a Trump rally or Trump supporters, sometimes you see
catch a viral video if I was going to.
And I was kind of just fascinated by like the whole dynamics of
So I thought that would be kind of like my moment of the day to kind of
And just like the amount of people that I heard were going to D.C., I thought
that alone could be a cool thing to video because I never really heard of like that many
people going to D.C. at once.
So I thought that would be kind of -- if there wasn't going to be any crazy
counterprotesting that I can record, I thought it would be just, you know, the mass

And I apologize again if you already answered
Were there any particular counterprotesters or types of
counterprotesters that you were interested in or did research on before you went to
I mean, the only group I've ever really heard of was antifa.
wasn't expecting them to show up necessarily.
I just thought it could be any type of
And then did you do any kind of research ahead of time or
were there people or accounts that you followed through social media that were giving
you information about what was going to happen on the 6th?
I really knew -- I honestly didn't even really
understand fully like politically what that day was until, you know, days after.
But, yeah, I didn't really know much except that there was a Trump rally and a
crazy amount of people were showing up.
to those days, that was really all I knew.
That was, you know, as far as like leading up
Did you have a sense of any -- so you knew there would be a lot of people
In terms of your thought that there might be counterprotesters, did you
have any sense of who the Trump supporters would be or what they would look like
Did I have a sense of what Trump supporters
I'm trying to get a sense, you were interested in the Trump
supporters, counterprotesters, and it seems like you have -- you had some at least sense
Did you have any thoughts of what the filming the Trump
But from what I've seen, it looked like mainly just normal dressed people in the
I mean, obviously some red hats and, you know, flags and whatnot.
videos besides, you know, the red hats and whatnot in like previous videos that I've seen
would usually dress in like all black, so you could tell the difference between the two.
So that was kind of, if I expected to see like a big clash, I expected to see, you
know, normal dressed people with flags, you know, Trump hats here and there, and then,
you know, whether it be all-black dressed individuals or not.
And then you would see, you know, the counterprotesters
That's kind of what I was
Did you ever see in previous videos people dressed in military fatigues
I want to say maybe, maybe I have, yeah.
Camouflage or other sort of tactical gear?
I can't say like for sure in my head what I've seen, but I feel like I may have
seen something similar, nothing like full military gear, but maybe like some brief
military-type equipment, like clothes and whatnot.
But I can't put anything specific in
And did you ever think before January 6th that if you saw a
clash it would be between maybe the people dressed up in the military and antifa?
No, I never really would expect anybody in military, like a group of, if that's
what you're saying, a group of like military-type people.
I know you said that your dad was going alone and that you wanted to
accompany him because you didn't feel comfortable with him doing that alone.
So did he ever talk about knowing of anybody else going or coordinating
with or making plans with anybody else?
I think -- he didn't have plans to go with anybody else or meet up with
anybody, but he did know friends that were in D.C. that he -- or that were going to D.C.
And I don't know if he had any plans to meet up with them or not, but at one
point in the day, which, you know, I'm sure we'll get to, we did separate, and he was
going to go try to find anybody that he knew that was there.
I think just individual friends, like maybe a guy and his wife, I think it was.
But I never met those friends of his, so I don't even know them by name.
Do you know, were these just kind of individual friends or was it a
group that he was part of?
Once you decided to go to D.C. for the 6th, did you post anywhere about
I don't even think I told anyone.
a fast thing, like, "All right, I guess I'm going."
And then how did you guys end up traveling down to D.C.?
Just in my dad's pickup truck.
Let's go through just some of the logistics of getting down there and when
Why don't you just start with, what day did you drive down?
On the 5th, the day before the rallies.
And then when did you arrive on the 5th?
I'd say sometime like mid-afternoon, early evening.
Did you guys do anything on the 5th?
We walked around D.C. a bit.
do, and we kind of just rode those around.
There were also some, you know,
Did you participate in any of those?
I honestly don't really remember, but
We actually -- we took the like rental
We don't have those in Philadelphia, so I thought it would be a fun thing to
And we ended up -- we did see some rallies and my dad wanted to stop for a bit.
But we weren't there very long.
Where did you stay when you were in D.C.?
Was it in D.C. proper or were you in northern Virginia?
It was in D.C. proper, yeah.
I don't remember the name though, unfortunately.
It took -- it took -- I would say, it was probably
Like I said, we took the scooters and we did bicycles anytime
we traveled into like the more metro areas.
But it would probably be about a
How did you travel down to the Mall area on the 6th?
I think it was by -- I can't remember if it was scooter or bike, but I want to
say it was the rental bikes.
And then why don't you just start me with the -- start with the
What did you do and then how did you end up going to the rally?
I think just woke up and had breakfast.
And then it was probably -- we
knew stuff was starting like early, like 8 or something, so we were up probably like 7.
And our plan was to just go to all these scheduled rallies, and then by then we
would already be checked out of our hotel, because it would be past the checkout time.
So we were just going to get back to the truck that was at the parking garage and try to
leave D.C. before, well before nightfall.
So, yeah, it was probably about 8 by the time we got down there after taking the
That was like our original plan.
And we kind of just cruised around for about an hour and just, you know, seeing
And then I don't remember exactly at what point we ended up going towards like
the big rally where Trump was speaking, but we did -- that was our first like main
Leading into the 6th, either the morning of or the day before, did you expect there
Let's stop there for one second.
to be any violence or -- on that day?
I thought there was a good possibility for it based off stuff I've seen from
other past stuff on the internet, but I had no indication that there would be like definitely
are groups of people who don't like these groups of people that live in this area, so
there's the potential for some clashes.
It was just like kind of more like a feeling, like, all right, like there
Did you do anything to prepare for that possibility, like change maybe what
Or did you bring any particular gear to prepare for that?
I really only had just like basic essentials, like I had like lunch and water
and I think a few Band-Aids if I got blisters on my feet and whatnot.
just very basic, you know, ChapStick and those kind of things.
And then I know you mentioned that you planned to go to the rally that
Trump was speaking at, that was at the Ellipse.
And then you said, I think, that you also planned to go to some rallies after
The only other one we really knew about that we planned on was the rally
that was scheduled at the Capitol.
it was like the perfect plan for us.
There was, I guess, one that was scheduled on, you
And that the Capitol was on our way back to our hotel, so
We'll leave here, stop at that rally on our way by, and
Do you know which rally that was, or do you remember what group was
We just -- we -- I think we were handed out like fliers or
something and then ended up seeing it, like maybe a 1 o'clock rally or something, I think
But -- and maybe my dad knew who they were, but I had no idea who it was.
And then do you remember what time you ended up arriving at the Ellipse
rally that President Trump was speaking at?
Sometime either late morning or early afternoon.
Why don't you -- so let's -- you just arrive at the Ellipse rally.
me through your experience of that rally specifically, and then we'll stop before you start
So I was just recording and we were
walking just, you know, getting the different angles and perspectives of the crowd that
We mainly stayed like in the back near the Washington Monument.
We did move up a little bit further into some deeper crowds, but there was just

So you went into the area.
So we just stuck towards the back.
Did you pass through metal detectors to get
So the big area where the Washington
Monument is, the big patch of grass, and there's a street dividing where the metal
50 feet down and it ended up being huge amounts of people.
We only got up as far as the street and, you know, walked maybe
We had no plan of going into the actual like metal
Do you remember any of the speeches in particular?
anybody whose name you remember speaking?
Only -- the only person I remember was Trump.
And were you there for -- oh, sorry, go ahead.
I was going to say, I really -- I wasn't even paying attention much, honestly,
so I couldn't even tell you what was said.
I was more like just amazed by the amount of people that were -- it was the
most amount of people I'd ever seen in one place, and I go to music festivals and stuff.
So it was kind of amazing just to see that many people.
What -- how would you describe the mood at that point during the Ellipse
That was really what I was more
A lot of smiling faces, high, happy, happy energy, you know, some people
with like -- I remember seeing there was somebody that had like a boom box, and people
And there was like a big -- there was like a huge like poster on the ground that
people were signing and, you know, little side stuff like that.
But it was pretty -- pretty good spirits honestly.
I know you said you don't recall the specifics of the speeches.
Do you remember anything specifically from his?
I mean, I've seen clips afterwards, you know, through different
media, but even those clips I barely even remember.
I could ask a few questions while you sort out your technical issues.
BYDo you recall the mood of the crowd changing at all during President
Not that I can recall, no.
Do you recall him telling people to go march towards the Capitol?
I believe I saw -- that was one of the clips I've seen.
him actually saying it in person.
And then what led you all to leave that rally and then go towards the
I think it was just tired of standing.
It was just time to just change
And, yeah, we just decided to get a move on.
And we also wanted to -- it was quite a walk.
So we wanted to try to see if we
could hop on one of those little scooters, the rental scooters.
kind of had to get ahead of the crowd a little bit in order to do that.
And at that point there was already massive amount of people flooding down that
direction, like a really good amount of people that had already been heading that way for
probably a good hour or so.
So when you left the rally had President Trump finished speaking?
I don't really remember, but I think he was still towards the end of his
Then how about just take me through from your kind of journey from the
Ellipse and then to the Capitol, and then we'll kind of stop when you get to the Capitol.
